Award.AwardTitle: Development of an interim passive ocean acoustic waveguide remote sensing system for instantaneous continental-shelf scale marine mammal monitoring, localization and species classi
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will provide a demonstration of the capability to provide wide-area marine mammal (MM) monitoring, localization and species classification in near real time using the passive ocean acoustic waveguide remote sensing (POAWRS) system.

The passive ocean acoustic waveguide remote sensing (POAWRS) system will combine the Lightweight Thinline Acoustic Receiver (LTAR) array system, funded with OCE MRI funding, and an integrated processing and analysis software package that provides detection, localization, tracking, feature extraction and species classification of MMs charted onto a geographic map of the region in near real time. This system has the potential to be a useful operational MM monitoring system used during field experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The passive ocean acoustics waveguide remote sensing (POAWRS)
technology uses a large-aperture densely-sampled array of hydrophones
to provide continuous monitoring of marine mammals over instantaneous
wide areas from their measured vocalizations. POAWRS monitoring
includes simultaneous detection, bearing-time estimation, species
classification, and localization of marine mammals vocalizations over
continental-shelf scale regions. POAWRS technology presents
significant advancement over current marine mammal sensing techniques
based on single hydrophone, sparse arrays and visual surveys.

(A) In this project, we developed and sea-tested a prototype 8-element
towable coherent hydrophone array hardware with real-time data
acquisition and 100 m tow cable in house at Northeastern University.
Each element consists of a piezoelectric ceramic transducer wired to a
preamplifier and connected to the tow cable. The tow cable contains 12
twisted pairs of wires providing power and ground to all
preamplifiers, and carrying output voltage signals of each of the 8
preamplifiers to a 32-channel analog-to-digital convertor (ADC)
hardware. The ADC is connected to a notebook computer for real-time
access and monitoring of the acoustic signals measured by each of the
8 hydrophone elements of the prototype array. We have written software
to convert the voltage signals to acoustic pressure signals by
correcting for hydrophone sensitivity, gain of the preamplifier and
the ADC conversion factor. The time-domain received signals and their
frequency-time spectrograms are plotted for each hydrophone and
updated periodically based on the data acquisition length. Each
hydrophone element is waterproofed using either poly-urethane or
silicon rubber. The shape of each element was designed to minimize
flow noise on the hydrophone array. Each element was tested in air
before and after waterproofing to ensure the element was acoustically
functional.  The prototype array has been tested underwater at the
Northeastern University swimming pool facility. The prototype
hydrophone array recorded a variety of sounds including tonal and
chirp pulses projected using an underwater loudspeaker from Lubell
Labs, as well as broadband clicks generated by clanging two wrenches
underwater.  The prototype array also recorded Led Zeppelin's
“Stairway to heaven” song that we projected underwater using the
Lubell Labs source.  The prototype array was tested at sea on a
recreational fishing vessel off the Boston harbor in about 30 m water
depth. The array was first deployed vertically with the ship's engines
shut off and we recorded broadband clicks and sea-surface reflections
by clanging 4 weights together underwater with a pole. The array was
then towed horizontally at roughly mid-water column at various tow
speeds around 3 to 4 knots and we recorded mostly ship sounds in the
busy Boston harbor.

(B) Under this project we significantly automated the POAWRS analysis
and processing software for real-time marine mammal sensing and
extending POAWRS for monitoring a large variety of other oceanic sound
sources.  The stages in POAWRS processing include (1) filtering of
hydrophone recorded pressure-time series data (sampled in the 8 kHz to
50 kHz range) in several frequency sub-bands of interest, (2)
beamforming of data from full or sub-apertures of the array spanning
360 degree azimuths about the receiver array to identify bearings
(horizontal azimuths) with potential strong sound sources, (3)
detection of sound sources via beamformed spectrogram analysis,
thresholding and clustering, (4) high-resolution beamforming to
determine bearing and time of detected sources more accurately, (5)
feature extraction via pitch tracking where features such as mean,
maximum and minimum frequency, duration, frequency-time slope (in Hz
per second), and 2nd and higher order curvature via polynomial curve
fitting for each sound source is determined, (6) detected signal
clustering incorporating methods in machine learning such as
centroid-based k-means and Bayesian distribution-based Gaussian
mixture models, (7) bearing-time association of signals within and
between clusters, (8) source bearing ambiguity resolution by
temporally correlating bearing-time sequences of classified and
associated signals with the array heading employing Kalman-filter and
Hough transform based bearing-time tracking approaches, (9)
localization of a sequence of associated sounds from their
bearing-time trajectories using a variety of techniques including the
moving array triangulation, the waveguide-based array invariant, and
the Kalman-filter based bearings-only tracking in modified polar
coordinates, (10) geographic positioning of localized sound sources in
latitude and longitude including bathymetric overlays and localization
mean and standard deviation ellipse, and (11) update of extracted
features and classification results into a database using a feedback
loop within the processing and analysis stages.  Currently many stages
of the POAWRS software have been connected and the rest will be
incorporated in the future. The automatic POAWRS software has been
tested and verified by application to coherent hydrophone array data
from two major oceanographic experiments: the Nordic Seas 2014
Experiment and the US Gulf of Maine 2006 Experiment. The results from
POAWRS analysis of marine mammal vocalizations from diverse species
and ship radiated noise have been published in four journal articles.
Our work has also been featured in various national and international
news media.
